content:
Diagnosis
	1. Intraductal papillary mucinous carcinoma (IPMN) of pancreatic body with liver, lung and peritoneal metastases

	Date of diagnosis
	January 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	Diagnostic laparoscopy and biopsy 15 Jan 2024

	Chemotherapy
	GEMCIS (Gemcitabine/Cisplatin) commenced 1 Feb 2024
	Cycle 1-2 completed at full dose
	Cycle 3 delayed and dose reduced due to neutropenia

	Clinical studies
	None

	Current disease status
	Progressive disease on imaging

	Current issues
	Deterioration in performance status
Increasing abdominal pain
Malignant ascites requiring drainage

	Summary of consultation

I reviewed [redacted name] today who has unfortunately shown clear evidence of disease progression despite initial GEMCIS chemotherapy. Recent CT imaging shows increase in size of liver metastases and new peritoneal deposits with associated ascites. Her performance status has declined from ECOG 1 to ECOG 2-3, largely due to increasing abdominal pain and fatigue. She has required two therapeutic paracenteses in the past month for symptomatic ascites.

The initial GEMCIS chemotherapy was complicated by grade 4 neutropenia after cycle 2, requiring a 2-week delay and subsequent 25% dose reduction. Despite this, she has developed progressive disease after 3 cycles.

After careful discussion with [redacted name] and her daughter today, we have agreed to discontinue GEMCIS and switch to weekly single-agent gemcitabine at a reduced dose of 800mg/m2. This decision takes into account her declining performance status and the need to prioritize quality of life while still attempting to slow disease progression.

	Further investigations
	Weekly FBC, U&Es, LFTs during treatment

	Medication prescribed
	Oxycodone MR 20mg BD increased from 10mg BD
Metoclopramide 10mg TDS PRN

	Follow up
	Weekly review during gemcitabine treatment
Urgent palliative care referral made

	Required GP actions
	Please monitor for increasing analgesic requirements
Early review if symptoms worsen

	Summary of information given to patient
	Discussed poor prognosis and aims of palliative chemotherapy
Provided written information about gemcitabine side effects
